title: Paula Butlewska sends postcards by balloon to her late dad from around the world
text:
6 shares 4
View
comments
A young woman has fulfilled her late father's retirement plans to travel the world - sending him postcards along the way.
Paula Butlewska enlisted the help of 20 close friends who love to travel to send postcards to her dad Edward, who passed away in 2012, during their trips abroad.
The dedicated daughter, aged 26, made sure Edward could follow their journey through the postcards addressed to heaven.
A young woman has enlisted the help of her friends to fulfil her late father's lifelong dreams of travelling the world. At each stop, she and her friends send a postcard to heaven. Pictured: a card sent from Chile
Paula Butlewska and 20 of her closest friends ensured that her dad Edward, who passed away in 2012, could follow along on their journey
More than 50 handwritten postcards were attached to balloons and released into the sky across Europe, Asia and America.
Paula visited six different countries on her journey: Chile, Peru, Bolivia, Spain, Belgium and the UK.

And her friends visited a total of 50 spots, including cities across Israel, Jordan, Ireland, USA, Albania, Italy, Germany, Turkey, France, Switzerland and Poland.
Paula, a PR Manager from Warsaw, Poland, set up a Facebook page to document the project.
Paula, who is from Warsaw, Poland, set up a Facebook page to document the project. Pictured: a postcard sent from Italy
As her friends travelled to far flung destinations like London (left) and Italy (right), they released postcards into the air
With the New York City skyline in the background, one of Paula's friends sent a postcard to her father from the Brooklyn Bridge
A group of Paula's friends, who were holidaying in the Philippines, were sure to send a handwritten message to her dad, Edward
One of Paula's friends, along with her young child, sent a postcard to heaven from Chile, attached to a purple balloon
Paula herself ventured to Chile, Peru, Bolivia, Spain, Belgium and the UK, while other friends (pictured) headed to Brazil
She said: 'My dad didn't manage to fulfil his dreams of travelling - he'd told me a lot about his plans for retirement.
'One evening I thought to myself, 'Dad, you'll go to all these places,' and I emailed my close friends about my idea.
'I believe it's never too late, so together with friends we travel for him.
'To make sure he knows about each trip we send him a postcard, to heaven. It's my therapy through the journey.'
Paula emailed her friends (like this one, pictured in Bolivia) when she realised that she could help her late father fulfil his retirement plans
Paula (pictured, left) wrote heartfelt messages on the balloons that she attached postcards to when sending them into the sky. Her friends, meanwhile, tossed a postcard into the air while in Iceland (right)
In Brussels, a male friend of Paula's attached his postcard to a blue balloon in a centre square - before snapping a quick picture
The postcard sent from the Philippines was released above the crystal clear ocean by several of Paula's good mates
To send Edward a postcard from England, a friend attached the note to a kite and stood on top of a hill
In Berlin, a friend sent a postcard into the sky while standing in the middle of the street (left) while Paula's friend's child tossed the postcard into the air in Iceland (right)
Paula and her friends travel to honour Edward's memory, after he tragically passed away at age 61 from a brain aneurysm. Pictured: two friends jumping with a postcard in Albania
A postcard is pictured at the Atacama Desert, located in South America and covering a 1,000-kilometre strip of land
Tragically Edward, a construction manager, suffered a brain aneurysm, aged 61, while driving, causing him to lose consciousness and hit a lorry.
Paula added: 'My dad was my buddy - we have exactly the same characters, he was a joker, a social butterfly and a really good man.
'I felt so angry when it first happened but this project has helped me. I feel I'm closer to him, or he's closer to me.
'When I see a postcard sent by my friends I understand exactly what 'the magic of friendships' means.'
